So first, I have to say what
a supporting hyperplane is. So a supporting hyperplane
is I have a set, it doesn't have to be convex.

And I have a point on the
boundary of the set here. And if you don't know
what the boundary is,

we could just take
that to be a completely informal that your
eyeball will tell you what's on the boundary.

So that's the point
on the boundary. And then a supporting
hyperplane is a hyperplane

that, very roughly speaking,
is tangent to the set here. And what it means is it
passes through this point,

but everything in this half
space is not in this set. Or another way to
say it is everything

this hyperplane tells
you that this set is on in one of the half spaces.

That's what it tells you. That's the supporting
hyperplane. And what it says is if
you have a convex set,

then there exists a supporting
hyperplane at every point. And that's not too, I mean,
it's kind of intuitive

that this would be the case. The picture would be
something like this.

Here's a convex set
C. And let's see,

And it's basically just--

Suppose there's a corner there. Let's talk about

Are there some? Is there more than one? Yes. Precisely.

That's it. So when you have a kink

to this set at this point?

No. No. So, that's what it
means, is that there

is no hyperplane at that point

on one side of it.

But by the way, the
converse is also true. If a set has a
supporting hyperplane at every point of its
boundary, then it's convex.
